instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2914: What is 820-2914? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
Hi,

I made a stupid thing while trying to fix a fan connector issue on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, shortcutting the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> to ground.

After that I'm sure something blown, because I heard it and I smell it.

Searching with microscope don't show anything damaged, but obviously the board is not working anymore. 

I'm trying to troubleshoot it. Actually <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is not present (I read 0). 

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> is present when the charger or the battery are connected (with the charger I read 16,48V).

On pin 8 and 2 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> I can read 3,86V (<SIGNAL>P3V42G3H_FB</SIGNAL>), but the output of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> is 0.

If a use a multimeter in diode mode on the output (red on ground and black on pin) I read 0,001 so I think I have a shortcut somewhere.

What is the best way to go on? Removing one by one the components on the line to find the one failing on injecting some power to find (I hope) the one heating?

Is the time worth or the shortcut on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> could have destroyed the board?

Thanks

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

A simple short on <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> shouldn't cause such damage.
You are "the lucky guy" in 1000, to happen this.

If you have pure short on <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, voltage injection method will locate the culprit rapidly.
Start with 1V and go up slowly (if needed), no more than 4V.
First, set amp limit of your lab PSU to max.

BTW, I hope you've measured diode mode after removing power.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 73337, member: 682"]
BTW, I hope you've measured diode mode after removing power.
[/QUOTE]
Sure

I will test the injection and see whats happen. 

Thanks

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
ok, strange things happen here. With voltage injection nothing start heating. But I see, after a while, that the current goes down to a low level. So I check again with diode mode the possible shortcircuit and it was gone :oops::oops:. The only thing that could be happen is that the shortcircuit was completely blown by the voltage injection....

So I try to connect the power supply to the board and I have got <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> again, and green led on the power supply connector.

I check some voltage values:

PPVBUS = 12,56V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = 4,90V

But the board don't start.

The system is charging the battery because after a while the green led became amber.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
Check the voltage on all big coils.
The fan spins?
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high?

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 73345, member: 682"]
Check the voltage on all big coils.
[/QUOTE]
I will check ASAP

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 73345, member: 682"]
The fan spins?
[/QUOTE]
No. Only a little when I remove power connector.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 73345, member: 682"]
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high?
[/QUOTE]
No

After a while I was able to find a very hot component. Is <CHIP>U4800</CHIP>. Is so hot I can't place a finger over it. I think it is gone. Could be the reason the board don't start? As I can understand is an infrared receiver. Could I remove it and try if the board start?

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
Remove and check if board turns on.
It is totally unnecessary thing...

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
Removed, no change.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> don't goes high.

About the coils:
L9710 = 0V
L3895 = 322mV
L7260 = 3,34V
L7720 = 1,81V
L7770 = 1,53V
L7220 = 5,01V
L8920 = 0V
L7550 = 0V
L7510 = 0V
L7520 = 0V
L7530 = 0V
L7030 = 12,55V
L7100 = 0V
L9560 = 1,51V
L7630 = 0V
L9510 = 1,02V
L7330 = 1,5V

I hope I don't miss someone.

System powered only by charger, no battery connected.

One more note: <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> stay warm, also if the board is not running.

Thanks

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
Missing <SIGNAL>1V05_S0</SIGNAL> and VCCSA.
Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> voltages.

Also check ohm resistance to ground at L7100 and L7630.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
All pin at 0, except 14 (20mV), 15 (3,29V), 20 (5V).

<CHIP>U7600</CHIP>
All pin at 0, except 3 (3,26V), 4 (0,5V), 7 (24mV), 8-10-11-12 (30mV), 13-14 (5V).

L7100 to ground 41,6 Ohm
L7630 tp ground 13 Ohm

Thanks

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
"<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
All pin at 0, except 14 (20mV), 15 (3,29V), 20 (5V)."
What about pin 19, surely 0V?
If yes, post diode mode to ground there.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
I checked again and I can confirm a 0V reading.

Checking in diode mode I have 0,001V, so shorted. I think <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR> shorted. Correct?

Also <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> seems strange. I read 44 Ohm instead of 2,2 expected from the schematic.

Thanks

threads.message: Removed <CAPACITOR>C7102</CAPACITOR>, but short still there.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
One step forward....

After replacing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> & <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> on L7100 I can read 0,911V. Should be 1,05V, correct?

But still no voltage on L7630.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
0.9V is good; did you look at VID1/0 table?
Don't make wrong assumptions so easy.

Post <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> voltages; pins 3, 13, 14.
Also check diode mode to ground at L7630.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 73896, member: 682"]
0.9V is good; did you look at VID1/0 table?
Don't make wrong assumptions so easy.
[/QUOTE]
Sorry, I look near L7100 on the schematic and I see Voltage=1.05, I don't see the table at all.

But at least I fixed something. This is good.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 73896, member: 682"]
Post <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> voltages; pins 3, 13, 14.
Also check diode mode to ground at L7630.
[/QUOTE]
Pin 3 = 3,26V
Pin 13 and 14 = 5V

L7630 seems shorted to ground (0,005V). I remove it (to understand where the short is) and I remove also <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR>, and seems the only pin shorted of <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR> is the number 2, but that pin is connected everywhere.... After the resistor removal no more short (obviously) in L7630.

threads.title: Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2914</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> after shortcut
threads.message:
Doesn't look to be short; compare with good board.

Change <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and check its solders, traces and surrounding components.

ok, good news.
